subject: Return early from RPC call handlers with no return value
commit_message:
Return early from RPC call handlers with no return value

Oslo messaging reminder:
cast: Send and forget. You only get an ACK from the messaging server,
not from the intended recipient.
call: Block until the recipient sends a return value or exception.

Agents often use call and not cast when updating about certain events,
even though the recipient (Neutron server in this case) has no return
value on the RPC endpoint (Think OVS agent update_device_up). The intention
is to notify that something happened, so naturally you don't care about
a return value. In the cases I observed there is no error handling in
the agents either.

Since there's no need to wait for a response or to see if the server
successfully updates whatever it is that it needs to update, we have
two choices:
a) Switch from call to cast in these cases
b) It can still be preferable to use call and not cast to get a
   stronger delivery guarantee. Perhaps you'd still want to bug out
   if the recipient is down or otherwise non-responsive.

Note: The oslo.notify API uses cast underneath so that's not a real
      alternative.

In this patch I propose B, because honestly it's easier for my puny
mind to imagine a world where when one side sends a message the other
side actually receives it, and not operate under an assumption where
notifications are non-reliable. Keeping that in mind, I prefer call to cast.
If this is way off base please do call me out!

To remedy the performance hit, I changed the RPC endpoints on the server
to process the message with eventlet.spawn_n, following a conversation
with sileht from Oslo messaging (This pattern is common in Nova).

Surprisingly, from my very simple tests with ml2.report_device_up,
this did not make a big difference from the agent's point of view.
It seems like most of the time in a call is spent in
Oslo messaging overhead or rabbit, but not processing the response on
the server. Still, this change could make an impact on other RPC messages
or when the neutron server is busy. It will also let us leverage ongoing
performance work in Oslo messaging such as:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/oslo.messaging/+bug/1437951

Change-Id: I012dfb709622b2a48705d6a999856c7ae93a7ca2

subject: Optimize ipset usage in IptablesFirewallDriver
commit_message:
Optimize ipset usage in IptablesFirewallDriver

Currently, IptablesFirewallDriver._update_ipset_members() iterates
through a list of security group IDs and makes a call to
IpsetManager.set_members() for each security group ID in the list. The
problem is that set_members() is repeatedly called with the same
arguments over and over again because the list of security group IDs
contains duplicates. These duplicated calls are unnecessary because they
are idempotent.

For instance, with a security group of 50 rules created in this manner:
    neutron security-group-rule-create $SECGRP --remote_group_id $SECGRP
        --protocol tcp --port_range_min $i --port_range_max $i

Adding a server to that security group will cause 50 calls to
IpsetManager.set_members() because the list of security group IDs is 50 of
the same ID. Only one call to IpsetManager.set_members() is necessary
per security group ID.

This patch converts that list of security group IDs into a set, which
eliminates the duplicate idempotent calls to
IpsetManager.set_members() with the same arguments. This will affect

subject: Ansible playbooks and roles to deploy OpenStack
commit_message:
Ansible playbooks and roles to deploy OpenStack

Request to add the os-ansible-deployment project to OpenStack namespace.
os-ansible-deployment (OSAD) is a project dedicated to deploying OpenStack
clouds using Ansible and upstream OpenStack source code without the addition
of vendor driven packaging.

This project is already using all of the OpenStack infrastructure and services
and is gated through gerrit with testing being done on the whole stack using
tempest on our three supported branches.

We are committed to furthering our mission of a great
developer/deployer/operator experience and intend to build out the system to
support all of the OpenStack named services.

We use the OpenStack dev/operators mailing list (albeit infrequently) and hold
meetings twice weekly[1] (one in our channel and the other in an official
OpenStack meeting channel which is logged[2]).

The IRC channel #openstack-ansible is logged[3], and active with community
members, core developers and like minted people all helping and disusing issues
within the project as well as questions that come us from using Ansible to
operate and manage clouds.

The scope of os-ansible-deployment is to provide tooling for deploying OpenStack
using ansible which will include contributing to the efforts of upstream
Ansible. We are already working with the community to ensure that our efforts
are not duplicated or being made in direct contrast to what upstream Ansible is
already providing. While we do have some overlap within our currently carried
modules, the OpenStack client modules we have in tree, we are committed to moving
that functionality and code into upstream just as we've done with our other
plugins/modules[4][5].

With this project's move to "big tent" we'd only be looking to bring with us the
Master and Kilo branches as they've been designed to be community code with
all of the original Rackspace-isms removed. This would mean that the Juno and
Icehouse branches would be left behind in StackForge as they'd not be part of
the mainline project but we, the community of developers working on OSAD, will
be supporting those code bases until they're EOL'd by the upstream OpenStack
projects.

This commit is a formal request to add os-ansible-deployment into the
OpenStack namespace as an official project.

[2] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/openstack_ansible_meeting/

To solve this problem we use two ipset rules to represent this.

This was correctly fixed in a backport to kilo though we did not have the
cycles to backport this exact fix to juno as in juno additional work needs to
be done because the iptable and ipset code are interleaved together. This
patch fixes this issue by disabling one from creating an address pair of
zero lenght. This patch also provides a small tool which one should run:
tools/fix_zero_length_ip_prefix.py which changes all zero length address_pair
rules into two address pair rules of:

Ipv4: 0.0.0.0/1 and 128.0.0.1/1
IPv6: ::/1' and '8000::/1

to avoid the problem.
After this patch is merged into juno it will be easier for us to apply
a better change to allow /0 addresses again in juno.

There isn't a reason to have a function to call this command
live in tempest-lib. The neutron-debug CLI is only used for
local debug and isn't actually a client. It's for running
locally on the same node as neutron. It's completely out of
scope for living in tempest-lib. Just because there is a
CLI for something in an OpenStack project running doesn't
mean we need to have a dedicated function to call it. It's
a simple matter to locally subclass the CLIClient class and
add local functions to call commands for a particular test
suite. 

So let's revert this before it's included in a release. If
it were to be included in a release the effort to remove it
goes up quite a bit, because we need a proper deprecation
cycle.

subject: Allow non-admin to list all tenants based on policy
commit_message:
Allow non-admin to list all tenants based on policy

Currently, running 'nova list --all-tenants' with a policy change:
"compute:get_all_tenants": "role:special_role or is_admin:True"

will not work as expected, The returned list of servers will not
contain all instances of all tenants. We should support administrators
who wish to enable this functionality in their policy.json.

We need to fix this problem both in the v2 API and in the v2.1 as well.

Deep in instance_get_all_by_filters_sort, there is a check which adds
a filter of project_id or user_id if the context is NOT an admin context.
So, the returned list will be a subset of all the instances in the
database. To fix this scenario, the easy way is to call get_all with
an elevated context to pass this check in instance_get_all_by_filters_sort.

So in fixing the bug above, we need to fix the default policy so that
all-tenants is available by default only to administrators.

SecurityImpact

APIImpact: --all-tenants will list all servers for non-admin

subject: API: Get a subset of fields from Nodes
commit_message:
API: Get a subset of fields from Nodes

Sometimes we don't care about all fields in a node (or a collection
of them) and only need a particular subset of fields for a particular
operation. This can save a lot of bandwidth depending on the information
contained in the nodes, for example, a node which contains a config drive
bsae64 encoded in it's instance_info field can be pretty heavy (a
collection of them ...)

This patch allows users to specify a list of fields that will be returned
when GET'ing a node or a collection of nodes.

E.g

Get the uuid, provision_state and power_state of a particular node:

  GET v1/nodes/<uuid>?fields=uuid,provision_state,power_state

Get the uuid, provision_state and power_state of a collection of nodes:

  GET v1/nodes?fields=uuid,provision_state,power_state

Get the uuid, provision_state and power_state of a particular node associated
with a particular instance:

  GET v1/nodes?fields=uuid,provision_state,power_state&instance_uuid=<instance uuid>

Since we are introducing a new feature in the API this patch bumps the
micro version to 1.8

APIImpact
